Award.AwardTitle: Revealing Ductility in Transition-Metal Carbides through Small Scale Experiments and Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports an investigation of the microscopic mechanisms governing fracture and plastic deformation in transition-metal carbides. Transition-metal carbides are a technologically important class of materials that are extremely hard, can withstand high-temperatures, and exhibit excellent resistance to wear, ablation, and corrosion. As a result, these materials are attractive for building hypersonic vehicles, spacecrafts, cutting tools, etc. However, they are generally believed to break easily at room temperature. The new knowledge gained from these studies can help develop superior performance, long-lasting, sustainable structural materials for use in a wider variety of applications. Therefore, the results of this research and the educational training of next-generation scientists and engineers will benefit the U.S. economy and society.

Transition-metal carbides, owing to a mixture of ionic, covalent, and metallic bonding, are expected to be intrinsically ductile even though they are generally considered to be brittle at room temperature. Motivated by the recent nanomechanical tests revealing ductility in single-crystals of these compounds, this project aims to develop fundamental understanding of the factors contributing to plasticity vs. fracture in these materials. To this purpose, a combination of in-situ electron microscopy based mechanical characterization and multi-scale modeling will be conducted at length scales between 0.1 and 3 micrometers. A new modeling framework, called the Discrete Dislocation & Crack Dynamics will be developed and has the potential for predicting concurrent plastic deformation and crack propagation in these materials. The research plans to reveal the role of crystal orientation, specimen size, transition-metal (group IV vs. V), and loading mode (tension, compression, and indentation) in determining dislocation microstructures, onset of fracture, and failure. These studies will improve the fundamental understanding of the physics of plastic deformation in transition-metal carbides and can likely enhance the life-time operation of advanced structural components used, for example, in aerospace and automotive industries, cutting tools, and hard coatings and may potentially lead to the design of tougher miniature structural components, such as micro- and nano-electromechanical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The group 4 and 5 transition metal-carbides (TMCs) and -nitrides (TMNs) are compounds with a mixture of ionic, covalent, and metallic bonds. Their mixed bonding results in a rather unique combination of properties: some of the highest known melting temperatures (2900 – 4300 K) where TaC has the highest melting point of the binary carbides or nitrides (4256 K) just below the sublimation point of graphite (4273 K), high hardness (10-30 GPa) between alumina and diamond, good thermal and electrical conductivities, and superior thermomechanical and chemical properties that allow for good wear, ablation, and corrosion resistance. They are a special class of materials within ultra-high temperature ceramics that are used as hard protective coatings, as high-temperature structural components in aerospace vehicles, and promising for operation in extreme environments (a combination of heat-, stress-, magnetic-, electric-, microwave-, and acoustic fields). Until recently, TMCs have been considered to be brittle under uniaxial loading at low temperatures, even though they are known to exhibit local plasticity during room-temperature microindentation. At high temperatures, the primary slip system for B1-structured TMCs is generally expected to be {111}[110]. However, studies have shown that other slip systems can be activated depending on temperature, orientation, and the transition-metal. As part of this project, we set out to systematically investigate the plastic deformation mechanisms operating in TMCs. As a first step, we chose single-crystals of group 5 TMCs (VC, NbC, and TaC) and experimentally studied their mechanical responses under uniaxial compression at room-temperature as a function of crystal orientation.

 Intellectual Merits:

Microcompression tests conducted on group 5 TMC single-crystals enabled accurate determination of the slip systems operating at room-temperature. These experiments also revealed that these crystals, depending on their orientation, can exhibit extensive plasticity. Our studies over the past three years have revealed several interesting and unexpected results. 1) In TaC single-crystals, we observed unusual orientation-dependent thermomechanical responses, which do not follow the Schmid's law. We attribute this behavior anomalous slip activity facilitated by lower normal resolved shear stresses. 2) In 100-oriented VC and NbC single-crystals subjected to uniaxial compression, we find that both {110}<110> and {111}<110> slip systems are active at room-temperature. 3) Compared to 111 and 100-oriented crystals, 110-oriented crystals exhibit the least amount of plasticity under compression.

 Broader Impacts:

The orientation and cation-dependent mechanical responses of group 5 TMCs will help develop better crystal plasticity models and design tougher ceramics. During the course of this project, two underrepresented minority doctoral candidates have been partially supported and one has graduated with a PhD this summer with another expected to graduate in winter next year. PI hosted another underrepresented undergraduate over the summer whose work will be part of a peer-reviewed publication later this year. Outcomes of this research will be used as course modules in PI's graduate-level course on 'Mechanical properties of non-metallic crystalline solids'.


Last Modified: 09/30/2019
Modified by: Suneel Kodambaka
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The group 4 and 5 transition metal-carbides (TMCs) and -nitrides (TMNs) are compounds with a mixture of ionic, covalent, and metallic bonds. Their mixed bonding results in a rather unique combination of properties: some of the highest known melting temperatures (2900 – 4300 K) where TaC has the highest melting point of the binary carbides or nitrides (4256 K) just below the sublimation point of graphite (4273 K), high hardness (10-30 GPa) between alumina and diamond, good thermal and electrical conductivities, and superior thermomechanical and chemical properties that allow for good wear, ablation, and corrosion resistance. They are a special class of materials within ultra-high temperature ceramics that are used as hard protective coatings, as high-temperature structural components in aerospace vehicles, and promising for operation in extreme environments (a combination of heat-, stress-, magnetic-, electric-, microwave-, and acoustic fields). Until recently, TMCs have been considered to be brittle under uniaxial loading at low temperatures, even though they are known to exhibit local plasticity during room-temperature microindentation. At high temperatures, the primary slip system for B1-structured TMCs is generally expected to be {111}[110]. However, studies have shown that other slip systems can be activated depending on temperature, orientation, and the transition-metal. As part of this project, we set out to systematically investigate the plastic deformation mechanisms operating in TMCs. As a first step, we chose single-crystals of group 5 TMCs (VC, NbC, and TaC) and experimentally studied their mechanical responses under uniaxial compression at room-temperature as a function of crystal orientation. Intellectual Merits: Microcompression tests conducted on group 5 TMC single-crystals enabled accurate determination of the slip systems operating at room-temperature. These experiments also revealed that these crystals, depending on their orientation, can exhibit extensive plasticity. Our studies over the past three years have revealed several interesting and unexpected results. 1) In TaC single-crystals, we observed unusual orientation-dependent thermomechanical responses, which do not follow the Schmid's law. We attribute this behavior anomalous slip activity facilitated by lower normal resolved shear stresses. 2) In 100-oriented VC and NbC single-crystals subjected to uniaxial compression, we find that both {110}<110> and {111}<110> slip systems are active at room-temperature. 3) Compared to 111 and 100-oriented crystals, 110-oriented crystals exhibit the least amount of plasticity under compression. Broader Impacts: The orientation and cation-dependent mechanical responses of group 5 TMCs will help develop better crystal plasticity models and design tougher ceramics. During the course of this project, two underrepresented minority doctoral candidates have been partially supported and one has graduated with a PhD this summer with another expected to graduate in winter next year. PI hosted another underrepresented undergraduate over the summer whose work will be part of a peer-reviewed publication later this year. Outcomes of this research will be used as course modules in PI's graduate-level course on 'Mechanical properties of non-metallic crystalline solids'.
